About Me

Hello, my name is Sundar and I am a tech-savvy Product Manager who has: road mapped, gathered and managed product requirements; developed products, applications and learnt from their success and failures; focused on problem space by leveraging technical instincts and capabilities with business acumen and domain knowledge.

I am most skilled in: Build and Maintain Products, Requirements Management, Analysis and Problem solving, and Legal, Content, and Payments domain consulting. Most importantly, I build trust and establish a lasting relationships with clients - without which I would fail in many aspects.

From Wikipedia: University of Madras is a public state university in Chennai (formerly Madras), Tamil Nadu, India. Established in 1857, it is one of the third oldest universities in India immediately after University of Calcutta and University of Mumbai .The university was incorporated by an act of the Legislative Council of India. University of Madras is the alma mater of two Indian Physics Nobel Laureates, CV Raman and Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar, five Presidents of India, including A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, and several notable mathematicians including Srinivasa Ramanujan.

During my time at University, I learnt and practiced most of my key skills such as analysis, problem solving and collaboration - they continue to help me throughout my career. I thoroughly enjoyed my time at university and learnt a lot outside the curriculum.

Backstories

1. The legacy Corrections platform was a major contributor ($3.5M) to the overall revenue of the program. While the program itself had been replatformed, the corrections was not yet moved to the new platform. The idea of any migration is to ensure a seemless movement from old to new for the customers. We had carefully planned the migration path to ensure this smooth transition by understanding the workflows and processes involved that had very intricate details such as redacting several areas. So, we built a platform where UIs and underlying interactions can be built on the go (customized instantly) and deployed at sites without a need for release.

2. The platform is a giant with millions of daily transaction. In order to understand the workflow of users and customers, I had built metrics and reports using Elastic DSL queries on Kibana platform. Also, in order to troubleshoot issues reported by customers, AWS logs were queried to understand their problems.

3. Similar to corrections solution, another application residing on older technology needed a migration. The caveat: (1) It had the highest ever NPS, (2) It was bringing in annual revenue of over $30M, and (3) Whole Product or nothing - monolithic migration, as the basic tenants of the product make up the entire product. The migration strategy needed to be constructed carefully so that it does not impact the customers migrating, and also has the least impact on learning. After extensive UX research, crude design sprints and many interviews later, we are on the cusp of releasing a product that will be superior to the Classic - and albeit numerous customer reviews and feedback on the alpha/beta/RC, one has to always learn from history - that we do not pull another Windows Vista 😉.

4. On more than one occasions, I had recommended and produced results that entirely eliminated the need to develop new solutions. With concepts around reusability, I make sure we do not expend unnecessarily.

5. AtTask was cloud-based a Project Management suite which was customized internally to track processes, the client wanted the workflow to be moved out of AtTask to Siebel CRM, I was invloved in this migration. I evaluated the cost parameters of existing license of AtTask and the cost involved in migration, and it did not make sense to make the move from AtTask. Thus, I had advised, based on my findings, to not to migrate - and they considered.
